Data Manipulation in R & Python

Using dplyr, data.table, pandas, and polars

data manipulation
dplyr
pandas

Published

July 9, 2024

    • Chain Expressions
    • Pivot Data

One of my favorite posts is the comparison between data.table and the tidyverse’s dplyr packages. Here is the link to that post. I have used that when trying to build my competence in using data.table. Now I’m going to try and expand on that by creating this post that compares cases of using dplyr, data.table, and now pandas. Hopefully this can be as useful as the comparison between dplyr an data.table post was for me. This is not an extensive way of comparing them but just to get started for anyone that wants to use python more.

Packages & Data

Code 
library(tidyverse)
library(data.table)

r_data <- tibble(
  x = rnorm(n = 1000),
  x2 = rnorm(n = 1000, sd = 3),
  y = rbinom(n = 1000, size = 1, prob = .6)
)

print(r_data)
# A tibble: 1,000 × 3
         x     x2     y
     <dbl>  <dbl> <int>
 1  0.409   1.17      1
 2 -0.846  -3.77      1
 3  0.0941 -2.09      1
 4  0.322   1.16      1
 5 -1.39    1.35      0
 6  1.26    6.09      1
 7  0.423  -2.02      1
 8  0.631  -0.861     1
 9  0.710  -0.134     0
10  0.0307 -0.592     1
# ℹ 990 more rows
Code 
r_table <- data.table(
  x = rnorm(n = 1000),
  x2 = rnorm(n = 1000, sd = 3),
  y = rbinom(n = 1000, size = 1, prob = .6)
)

print(r_table)
               x         x2     y
           <num>      <num> <int>
   1: -0.1754454 -0.3782700     0
   2: -0.9763540 -1.3373400     1
   3:  0.8446304 -0.2514460     0
   4: -0.5736134  2.5926507     1
   5: -0.8102045 -2.5416087     1
  ---                            
 996: -0.1662248  4.1958309     1
 997: -2.3012591 -3.2231485     0
 998: -0.3347386 -0.9638556     0
 999:  0.5013931 -1.2036860     1
1000:  0.4185055 -0.5018234     1
Code 
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

data = {
    'x': np.random.normal(0, scale=1, size=1000),
    'x2': np.random.normal(0, scale=3, size=1000),
    'y': np.random.binomial(n=1, p=0.6, size=1000)
}

# Creating DataFrame
py_data = pd.DataFrame(data)

print(py_data)
            x        x2  y
0    1.120220  3.810238  1
1    0.947493 -4.892057  0
2    0.679544 -0.393661  0
3    0.134986 -0.321329  1
4    0.551375 -1.034227  0
..        ...       ... ..
995  1.635647 -1.750633  1
996 -0.604228  3.279034  0
997  0.428933  0.942513  0
998  1.734978 -4.543330  0
999 -0.218969  4.305527  0

[1000 rows x 3 columns]
Code 
import polars as pl

pl_data = pl.DataFrame(data)

print(pl_data)
shape: (1_000, 3)
┌───────────┬───────────┬─────┐
│ x         ┆ x2        ┆ y   │
│ ---       ┆ ---       ┆ --- │
│ f64       ┆ f64       ┆ i32 │
╞═══════════╪═══════════╪═════╡
│ 1.12022   ┆ 3.810238  ┆ 1   │
│ 0.947493  ┆ -4.892057 ┆ 0   │
│ 0.679544  ┆ -0.393661 ┆ 0   │
│ 0.134986  ┆ -0.321329 ┆ 1   │
│ 0.551375  ┆ -1.034227 ┆ 0   │
│ …         ┆ …         ┆ …   │
│ 1.635647  ┆ -1.750633 ┆ 1   │
│ -0.604228 ┆ 3.279034  ┆ 0   │
│ 0.428933  ┆ 0.942513  ┆ 0   │
│ 1.734978  ┆ -4.54333  ┆ 0   │
│ -0.218969 ┆ 4.305527  ┆ 0   │
└───────────┴───────────┴─────┘

Basic Operations

Filtering (Integers)

Code 
r_data |>
  filter(
    x > 1
  ) |>
  head()
# A tibble: 6 × 3
      x    x2     y
  <dbl> <dbl> <int>
1  1.26  6.09     1
2  1.13 -1.44     1
3  2.12  2.60     0
4  1.00  2.13     1
5  1.59  3.99     1
6  2.20 -1.62     1
Code 
head(
  r_table[x > 1]
)
          x         x2     y
      <num>      <num> <int>
1: 1.674498  3.6659813     0
2: 3.004482  3.0656903     1
3: 2.551585  8.1276025     1
4: 1.733821 -0.8900152     1
5: 1.263874 -1.2767909     1
6: 1.540138  3.6267555     0
Code 
py_data[py_data["x"] > 1].head()
           x        x2  y
0   1.120220  3.810238  1
20  1.515091  1.237811  0
28  2.129698  3.715099  1
29  1.028248  0.270362  1
33  1.886046  0.232325  1
Code 
pl_data.filter(pl.col('x') > 1).head()
shape: (5, 3)
x x2 y
f64 f64 i32
1.12022 3.810238 1
1.515091 1.237811 0
2.129698 3.715099 1
1.028248 0.270362 1
1.886046 0.232325 1

Filtering (Categorical)

Code 
r_data |>
  filter(
    y == 1
  ) |>
  head()
# A tibble: 6 × 3
        x    x2     y
    <dbl> <dbl> <int>
1  0.409   1.17     1
2 -0.846  -3.77     1
3  0.0941 -2.09     1
4  0.322   1.16     1
5  1.26    6.09     1
6  0.423  -2.02     1
Code 
head(
  r_table[y == 1]
)
            x         x2     y
        <num>      <num> <int>
1: -0.9763540 -1.3373400     1
2: -0.5736134  2.5926507     1
3: -0.8102045 -2.5416087     1
4: -0.4948199  0.4980446     1
5:  0.5398953  3.0874990     1
6:  0.1005187  0.3697423     1
Code 
py_data[py_data["y"] == 1].head()
          x        x2  y
0  1.120220  3.810238  1
3  0.134986 -0.321329  1
5 -1.493926  3.362695  1
8  0.907419  4.916472  1
9 -0.244917 -3.831616  1
Code

-1.493926 3.362695 1

-0.244917 -3.831616 1

Filtering Multiple Columns

Code 
r_data |>
  filter(
    y == 1 &
    x2 < 0
  ) |>
  head()
# A tibble: 6 × 3
        x     x2     y
    <dbl>  <dbl> <int>
1 -0.846  -3.77      1
2  0.0941 -2.09      1
3  0.423  -2.02      1
4  0.631  -0.861     1
5  0.0307 -0.592     1
6  0.759  -4.35      1
Code 
head(
  r_table[
    y == 1 &
    x2 > 0
  ]
)
            x        x2     y
        <num>     <num> <int>
1: -0.5736134 2.5926507     1
2: -0.4948199 0.4980446     1
3:  0.5398953 3.0874990     1
4:  0.1005187 0.3697423     1
5:  0.2489273 3.2787428     1
6: -1.4057361 3.9976275     1
Code 
py_data[
  (py_data["y"] == 1) & 
  (py_data["x2"] > 0)
    ].head()
           x        x2  y
0   1.120220  3.810238  1
5  -1.493926  3.362695  1
8   0.907419  4.916472  1
15  0.091052  1.497482  1
17 -0.438709  0.148849  1
Code 
pl_data.filter(pl.col('y') == 1, pl.col('x2') > 0).head()
shape: (5, 3)
x x2 y
f64 f64 i32
1.12022 3.810238 1
-1.493926 3.362695 1
0.907419 4.916472 1
0.091052 1.497482 1
-0.438709 0.148849 1
Code 
# uses a comma instead of using &

Sorting Rows

Code 
r_data |> 
  arrange(y) |>
  head()
# A tibble: 6 × 3
        x     x2     y
    <dbl>  <dbl> <int>
1 -1.39    1.35      0
2  0.710  -0.134     0
3 -2.00    0.169     0
4 -0.116  -4.16      0
5  0.328  -2.07      0
6 -0.0749  3.35      0
Code 
head(
  r_table[order(y)]
)
            x         x2     y
        <num>      <num> <int>
1: -0.1754454 -0.3782700     0
2:  0.8446304 -0.2514460     0
3: -0.1584563  1.2388419     0
4:  1.6744982  3.6659813     0
5:  0.1953033 -6.5178594     0
6:  0.2178685 -0.9440392     0
Code 
py_data.sort_values(by = "y").head()

990  0.073119  2.523895  0
989  0.764942 -0.644956  0

984  1.247925  2.175303  0
Code

Selecting Specific Columns

Code 
r_data |>
  select(
    y
  ) |>
  head()
# A tibble: 6 × 1
      y
  <int>
1     1
2     1
3     1
4     1
5     0
6     1
Code 
head(
  r_table[,"y"]
)
       y
   <int>
1:     0
2:     1
3:     0
4:     1
5:     1
6:     0
Code 
py_data["y"].head()
0    1
1    0
2    0
3    1
4    0
Name: y, dtype: int32
Code 

# py_data.filter(items = "y").head()
Code 
pl_data.select(pl.col('y')).head()
shape: (5, 1)
y
i32
1
0
0
1
0

Selecting Multiple Columns

Code 
r_data |> 
  select(x, x2) |> 
  head()
# A tibble: 6 × 2
        x    x2
    <dbl> <dbl>
1  0.409   1.17
2 -0.846  -3.77
3  0.0941 -2.09
4  0.322   1.16
5 -1.39    1.35
6  1.26    6.09
Code 
head(
  r_table[,list(x, x2)]
)
            x        x2
        <num>     <num>
1: -0.1754454 -0.378270
2: -0.9763540 -1.337340
3:  0.8446304 -0.251446
4: -0.5736134  2.592651
5: -0.8102045 -2.541609
6: -0.1584563  1.238842
Code 
py_data[["x", "x2"]].head()
          x        x2
0  1.120220  3.810238
1  0.947493 -4.892057
2  0.679544 -0.393661
3  0.134986 -0.321329
4  0.551375 -1.034227
Code 
# or
py_data.filter(items = ["x", "x2"]).head()
          x        x2
0  1.120220  3.810238
1  0.947493 -4.892057
2  0.679544 -0.393661
3  0.134986 -0.321329
4  0.551375 -1.034227
Code 
pl_data.select(pl.col('x'), pl.col('x2')).head()
shape: (5, 2)
x x2
f64 f64
1.12022 3.810238
0.947493 -4.892057
0.679544 -0.393661
0.134986 -0.321329
0.551375 -1.034227

Selecting Using Regex

Code 
r_data |>
  select(
    matches("x")
  ) |>
  head()
# A tibble: 6 × 2
        x    x2
    <dbl> <dbl>
1  0.409   1.17
2 -0.846  -3.77
3  0.0941 -2.09
4  0.322   1.16
5 -1.39    1.35
6  1.26    6.09
Code 
cols <- grep("^x", names(r_table))

head(
  r_table[, ..cols]
)
            x        x2
        <num>     <num>
1: -0.1754454 -0.378270
2: -0.9763540 -1.337340
3:  0.8446304 -0.251446
4: -0.5736134  2.592651
5: -0.8102045 -2.541609
6: -0.1584563  1.238842
Code 
py_data.filter(regex = "x").head()
          x        x2
0  1.120220  3.810238
1  0.947493 -4.892057
2  0.679544 -0.393661
3  0.134986 -0.321329
4  0.551375 -1.034227
Code 
import polars.selectors as cs

pl_data.select(cs.starts_with('x')).head()
shape: (5, 2)
x x2
f64 f64
1.12022 3.810238
0.947493 -4.892057
0.679544 -0.393661
0.134986 -0.321329
0.551375 -1.034227

Summarize Data

Code 
r_data |>
  summarize(
    avg = mean(x)
  )
# A tibble: 1 × 1
      avg
    <dbl>
1 -0.0366
Code 
  r_data |>
  summarize(
    total = sum(x)
  )
# A tibble: 1 × 1
  total
  <dbl>
1 -36.6
Code 
r_table[, .(avg = mean(x))]
          avg
        <num>
1: 0.05005754
Code 
r_table[, .(total = sum(x))]
      total
      <num>
1: 50.05754
Code 
py_data["x"].mean()
np.float64(0.04849950488018116)
Code 
py_data["x"].sum()
np.float64(48.49950488018116)
Code 
pl_data.select(pl.mean('x'))
shape: (1, 1)
x
f64
0.0485
Code 
pl_data.select(pl.sum('x'))
shape: (1, 1)
x
f64
48.499505

Adding/Updating/Deleting Columns

Code 
r_data <- r_data |>
  mutate(
    x_mult = x*x2
  )
head(r_data)
# A tibble: 6 × 4
        x    x2     y x_mult
    <dbl> <dbl> <int>  <dbl>
1  0.409   1.17     1  0.478
2 -0.846  -3.77     1  3.18 
3  0.0941 -2.09     1 -0.197
4  0.322   1.16     1  0.374
5 -1.39    1.35     0 -1.88 
6  1.26    6.09     1  7.67
Code 
r_table[, x_mult := x*x2]
head(r_table[, "x_mult"])
        x_mult
         <num>
1:  0.06636573
2:  1.30571727
3: -0.21237892
4: -1.48717919
5:  2.05922268
6: -0.19630230
Code 
py_data["x_mult"] = py_data["x"] * py_data["x2"]
py_data["x_mult"].head()
0    4.268305
1   -4.635190
2   -0.267510
3   -0.043375
4   -0.570247
Name: x_mult, dtype: float64
Code 
pl_data.with_columns((pl.col('x') * pl.col('x2')).alias('x_mult'))
shape: (1_000, 4)
x x2 y x_mult
f64 f64 i32 f64
1.12022 3.810238 1 4.268305
0.947493 -4.892057 0 -4.63519
0.679544 -0.393661 0 -0.26751
0.134986 -0.321329 1 -0.043375
0.551375 -1.034227 0 -0.570247
… … … …
1.635647 -1.750633 1 -2.863418
-0.604228 3.279034 0 -1.981286
0.428933 0.942513 0 0.404275
1.734978 -4.54333 0 -7.882577
-0.218969 4.305527 0 -0.942777

Counting

Code 
r_data |> count(y)
# A tibble: 2 × 2
      y     n
  <int> <int>
1     0   406
2     1   594
Code 
r_table[, .N, by = (y)]
       y     N
   <int> <int>
1:     0   400
2:     1   600
Code 
py_data["y"].value_counts()
y
1    581
0    419
Name: count, dtype: int64
Code 
pl.Series(pl_data.select(pl.col('y'))).value_counts()
shape: (2, 2)
y count
i32 u32
0 419
1 581

Group By

Code 
r_data |>
  group_by(y) |>
  summarize(
    avg = mean(x)
  )
# A tibble: 2 × 2
      y     avg
  <int>   <dbl>
1     0 -0.0440
2     1 -0.0316
Code 
r_table[, .(avg = mean(x)), by = "y"]
       y         avg
   <int>       <num>
1:     0 0.001986386
2:     1 0.082104971
Code 
py_data.groupby("y")["x"].mean()
y
0    0.095591
1    0.014539
Name: x, dtype: float64
Code 
pl_data.group_by('y').agg(pl.col('x').mean())
shape: (2, 2)
y x
i32 f64
1 0.014539
0 0.095591

Chain Expressions

Code 
r_data |>
  group_by(y) |>
  summarize(
    avg = mean(x)
  ) |>
  filter(
    y == 1
  )
# A tibble: 1 × 2
      y     avg
  <int>   <dbl>
1     1 -0.0316
Code 
r_table[, 
  by = y,
  .(avg = mean(x))
  ][
    y == 1
  ]
       y        avg
   <int>      <num>
1:     1 0.08210497
Code 
py_group = py_data.groupby("y")["x"].mean().reset_index()

py_group.iloc[1:, ]
   y         x
1  1  0.014539
Code 
pl_group = pl_data.group_by('y').agg(pl.col('x').mean())

pl_group.filter(pl.col('y') == 1)
shape: (1, 2)
y x
i32 f64
1 0.014539

Pivot Data

Code 
r_data |>
  pivot_longer(
    -y
  ) |>
  head()
# A tibble: 6 × 3
      y name    value
  <int> <chr>   <dbl>
1     1 x       0.409
2     1 x2      1.17 
3     1 x_mult  0.478
4     1 x      -0.846
5     1 x2     -3.77 
6     1 x_mult  3.18
Code 
head(melt(r_table, id.vars = "y"))
       y variable      value
   <int>   <fctr>      <num>
1:     0        x -0.1754454
2:     1        x -0.9763540
3:     0        x  0.8446304
4:     1        x -0.5736134
5:     1        x -0.8102045
6:     0        x -0.1584563
Code 
py_data.melt(id_vars = ['y'], value_vars = ['x', 'x2', 'x_mult']).head()
   y variable     value
0  1        x  1.120220
1  0        x  0.947493
2  0        x  0.679544
3  1        x  0.134986
4  0        x  0.551375
Code 
pl_data.unpivot(index = 'y').head()
shape: (5, 3)
y variable value
i32 str f64
1 "x" 1.12022
0 "x" 0.947493
0 "x" 0.679544
1 "x" 0.134986
0 "x" 0.551375
